headline.seo: New York Had Most Tourists in 2010, Bloomberg Says
headline.print_headline: Mayor Says Tourism Hit Record High in 2010
headline.main: New York Tourism Hit Record High in 2010, Mayor Says

docs.lead_paragraph: Visitors, many flush with foreign currencies with extra buying power, spent $31 billion in the city, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced.
docs.snippet: Visitors, many flush with foreign currencies with extra buying power, spent $31 billion in the city, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced....

docs.abstract: Aruba is working on running on renewable energy, and a number of its resorts offer green options for travelers.

headline.print_headline: Tim Bewer on Ethical Elephant Tourism in Thailand.

docs.abstract: Travel Q&A with Tim Bewer, co-funder of Thailand-based private tour company Isan Explorer, who discusses changes he made to elephant portion of tours to focus on animals' well-being.
docs.lead_paragraph: Tim Bewer of the tour company Isan Explorer offers elephant activities that break with tradition — no rides or shows but plenty of walking.
docs.snippet: Tim Bewer of the tour company Isan Explorer offers elephant activities that break with tradition — no rides or shows but plenty of walking....

docs.abstract: There are culinary wonders to be had in Iowa.
docs.lead_paragraph: That's what the Iowa Arts Council is pushing and, while I am not jumping into the jalopy or logging on to book a ticket, I do find this little presentation a convincing bundle of evidence that wonderful eating is possible wherever there is good land and decent weather. (Hat tip to Mike at www.notionscapital.com.)

docs.abstract: Joseph Panza letter, commenting on Sept 5 article on downturn in tourism in New York City, says situation will worsen if proposed laws prohibiting smoking in bars and restaurants are enacted
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''More Visitors, Less Spending in New York'' (news article, Sept. 5) notes that our cherished international tourist trade is suffering. I believe that it will suffer even further if Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's proposed smoking laws go into effect.
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    ''More Visitors, Less Spending in New York'' (news article, Sept. 5) notes that our cherished international tourist trade is suffering.     I believe that it will suffer even further if Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's proposed smoki...

docs.abstract: New York Convention and Visitors Bureau has begun major campaign to lure tourists with discounts at 250 hotels, restaurants, stores and cultural institutions; campaign is scheduled to run through end of March (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Tourism is booming in New York City. According to the latest estimates, 30.3 million people visited the city last year, pouring $13 billion into the local economy. So why is the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau rolling out a major campaign to lure tourists with discounts at 250 hotels, restaurants, stores and cultural institutions? Two words: The cold. ''We have now entered the slowest time of the year for the 25,000 tourism-related businesses and their 130,000 employees,'' said Stephen J. Morello, the bureau's president. ''It's not because we have less to offer but because the weather makes us less competitive. We can't sit back and let the city sell itself.''

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: Tourism in Puerto Rico appears to have been unaffected by the New Year's Eve fire at the Dupont Plaza Hotel that killed 96 people, Mayor Baltasar Corrada del Rio of San Juan said today. ''This is very encouraging,'' he said, citing figures he said showed hotel occupancy rates increased about 12 percent in the first two weeks of January.
